questions.text: A 48y woman comes to the clinic due to dyspareunia which has worsened over the last 4 months. Five years ago, she underwent chemoradiation for stage 2 cervical cancer. She has only recently resumed sexual activity after a gap of about 5 years. Despite over the counter use of lubricants, she is till having pain. There is no postcoital bleeding. She is amenorrhoeic since the chemoradiation. On examination, the vaginal introitus is narrow and the vagina is pale. The cervix appears scarred but there is no growth or ulcer and does not bleed on touch. What is the likely cause of her dyspareunia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Atrophic Vaginitis

questions.text: A 15y girl with primary amenorrhea is diagnosed to have Turner Syndrome. What Hormone replacement therapy should be given?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Growth hormone + E + P

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most girls with Turner require hormone replacement therapy for breast development, uterine growth, and bone health. The consensus is to initiate hormone replacement therapy at a time that coincides with normal female pubertal development. Initial hormone replacement involves low dose estrogen monotherapy. Progestogen replacement is generally added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

questions.text: A 54y woman presents to the OPD with several months of irregular vaginal spotting. She does not give a history of heavy bleeding but only that her undergarments are stained with blood. She attained menopause at the age of 52 and she had hot flushes and night sweats for which she was started on the transdermal estrogen patch and progesterone only pills. She has been consistently using the estrogen patches but stopped the progesterone in view of severe nausea. She has no significant medical history. She is on regular HPV screening and her last HPV was done 2 year earlier which was normal. Speculum exam reveals a normal cervix and vagina with minimal blood in the upper vagina. Bimanual exam reveals a small uterus with no adnexal mass. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop the estrogen patch and place an LNG-IUD

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Transvaginal ultrasound

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains that she has not had a period for 3 months. Four home pregnancy tests have all been negative. She started her periods at the age of 15 years and until 30 years she had a normal 28-day cycle. She had one daughter by normal delivery 2 years ago, following which she breast-fed for 6 months. After that she had normal cycles again for several months and then her periods stopped abruptly. She was using the progesterone only pill for contraception while she was breastfeeding and stopped 6 months ago as she is keen to have another child. She reports symptoms of dryness during intercourse and has experienced sweating episodes at night as well as episodes of feeling extremely hot at any time of day. The only medical history of note is that she has been hypothyroid for 10 years and takes thyroxine 100 mg per day. She does not take any alcohol, smoke or use recreational drugs. On lab investigation FSH level is 45 IU/L. what is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Delay in return of fertility after contraception

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Premature ovarian failure
